Health Sector Development Program (RRP BHU 51141-002) 
I.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
 
1.  Despite  its  impressive  gains  in  health  outcomes,  Bhutan  still  faces  considerable 
challenges to sustain and further improve health sector performance. The rise in lifestyle-related 
noncommunicable diseases is significantly driving up the cost of health care. Rapid urbanization 
has also created new gaps in service coverage, leaving a growing urban migrant population 
underserved.  At  the  same  time,  the  health  sector  still  grapples  with  persistent  regional 
disparities in health outcomes and service coverage. Moreover, health security risks to this 
once-secluded country have increased because of growing cross-border activities, direct air 
connectivity with large regional hubs, and reliance on a large number of expatriate workers. 
Sustainable health financing also needs critical attention given the rising costs of health care 
amid the backdrop of significantly reduced donor assistance. Several structural constraints 
make it difficult for Bhutan to tackle these evolving problems, including (i) inadequate primary 
health care (PHC) service delivery; (ii) insufficient health sector financing; and (iii) inefficient 
sector management, particularly fragmented health information management. 
 
2.  The  sector  development  program  (SDP)  will  support  efforts  of  the  government  to 
improve the equity, efficiency, and sustainability of Bhutan’s health system. The SDP comprises 
(i) a project, financed by a project grant, to invest in PHC improvements; and (ii) a program, 
financed by a policy-based grant, to support governance and institutional improvements in the 
areas of health financing and health information management. The SDP will also advance 
Bhutan’s  health  security  agenda  through  strategic  support  for  prevention  and  control  of 
infectious diseases in line with Bhutan’s commitment to the International Health Regulations 
(2005). 
 
3.  Impact, outcome, and outputs. The impact is aligned with the National Health Policy 
vision for a healthy and happy nation. The outcome will be that equitable access, efficiency, and 
financial sustainability of the health system have improved. The SDP will have three outputs. The 
project grant will support output 1 for PHC service delivery improvements in selected areas. The 
policy-based grant will support outputs 2 and 3 for more health financing and stronger health 
information management.  
 
4.  Output 1: Primary health services in underserved areas improved. This project-
based output will support improvements in PHC service delivery, especially in underserved 
areas.  Investments  will  support  (i)  the  construction  of  five  PHC  satellite  clinics  in  urban 
peripheries of Thimphu and Phuentsholing; (ii) upgrades to primary health facilities resulting in 
better  infrastructure  provisions  for  infection  control  and  waste  management;  (iii)  medical 
equipment for enhanced PHC service delivery, including immunization and transportation of 
laboratory samples; (iv) capacity development of health workers to roll out the Bhutan Health 
Standards and Quality Assurance mechanism at primary health facilities; and (v) public health 
advocacy and behavior change communication through civil society organizations.  
 
5.  Output 2: Health sector financing enhanced. This policy-based output will bolster 
health financing by improving equity and sustainability of the Bhutan Health Trust Fund (BHTF), 
whose core mandate includes financing vaccines and supporting immunization, in line with 
International Health Regulation requirements. The policy actions cover measures to (i) enhance 
the BHTF’s operations by strengthening its capital base, capacity, and governance; (ii) make the 
distribution of benefits from public health financing more equitable based on a benefit-incidence 
analysis; and (iii) develop the legal basis that governs health financing equity, efficiency, and 
sustainability in the form of a health bill. Budget support provided by the Asian Development

2 
Bank  (ADB)  under  this  output  will  help  the  BHTF  to  increase  its  capital  and  diversify  its 
investments.  
 
6.  Output  3:  Disease  surveillance  and  health  information  system  enhanced. This 
policy-based output will improve sector management efficiency by catalyzing transformative 
change in Bhutan’s health information management, including for effective disease surveillance. 
The program will facilitate the country’s incremental move to an interoperable national health 
information system (HIS) from the now fragmented individual systems that are often redundant 
and ineffective to support decision-making in critical areas of health and disease management. 
Policy actions include (i) development and adoption of a national e-health strategy, (ii) creation 
of an HIS governing body, (iii) development and adoption of an HIS enterprise architecture for 
interoperability,  and  (iv)  development  and  adoption  of  technical  standards  for  health  data 
exchange.  
 
7.  Overall financing. The SDP is estimated to cost $41.22 million. ADB will provide a grant 
of $20 million, comprising a project grant of $6 million equivalent, and a policy-based grant of 
$14 million. The government will provide counterpart funds totaling $21.22 million equivalent.  
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
8.  The transaction technical assistance (TA) will support the implementation of the policy-
based component of the SDP and assist the government in meeting the tranche conditions. The 
government  and  the  BHTF  require  high-quality  technical  inputs  and  effective  institutional 
capacity development through this TA to ensure that they meet the SDP policy objectives—
(i) BHTF is strengthened as a self-sustaining financial entity and can finance essential drugs 
and required vaccines on a sustainable basis; (ii) benefits from public financing of health in 
Bhutan are more pro-poor and equitably distributed; and (iii) a strong and interoperable national 
HIS is established that meets Bhutan’s data needs, including for effective disease surveillance 
and patient management. The TA is included in ADB’s country operations business plan, 2018–
2020 for Bhutan.1 
 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
9.  The proposed TA will have two outputs aligned with the SDP to help the government 
enhance (i) health sector financing and (ii) the HIS. The broad activities to be supported include 
strengthening the financial and institutional capacity of the BHTF, bolstering the capacity of the 
Ministry  of  Health  (MOH)  in  health  economics,  and  assisting  the  MOH  in  developing  the 
framework for an interoperable national HIS and strengthening e-health governance. 
 
1.  Output 1: Health Sector Financing Enhanced  
 
10.  Bhutan Health Trust Fund capacity. This output will strengthen (i) the BHTF’s financial 
and institutional capacity and (ii) the MOH’s capacity in health economics to support key policy 
decisions. The activities to bolster the BHTF’s financial and fund management capacity involve 
(i) resource planning (e.g., 3-year rolling resource planning on an annual basis); (ii) quarterly 
investment  management  reporting  and  analysis  (e.g.,  risk-return  reporting,  performance 
analysis,  investment  decision,  market  snapshot,  benchmarking  domestic  and  offshore 
                                                
1   ADB. 2017. Country Operations Business Plan: Bhutan, 2018–2020. Manila.

3 
investments); and (iii) basic training on investment management through a consulting firm. 
Support  for  enhanced  BHTF  institutional  functions  include  strengthening  its  (i)  operations 
manual and providing implementation guidance; (ii) accounting capacity and procedures (i.e., 
improving system, staff, and methodology); and (iii) capacity for mobilizing funds, including 
through web design and public communication. 
 
11.  Ministry  of  Health  policy  development.  The  TA  will  also  strengthen  the  MOH’s 
capacity in health economics to guide policy decisions. This includes assistance in (i) analytical 
work to support the long-term health financing vision, and provide evidence for financing policy 
products, such as updated benefit-incidence analysis; and (iii) identifying and advocating ways 
to improve the efficiency of health spending.  
 
2.  Output 2: Health Information System Enhanced  
  
12.  This  output  will  assist  the  MOH  in  developing  a  national  HIS  with  interoperable 
enterprise  architecture  and  strengthening  digital  governance.  It  involves  (i)  reviewing  the 
different systems for data-sharing needs, the target system in which data should be shared, as 
well as the data elements; (ii) integrating data from all systems into the national data warehouse 
to generate all required reports; and (iii) developing the specifications for an interoperable 
electronic patient information system and for disease surveillance. To anchor and guide policy 
direction and planning, the output would also help strengthen the legal and policy environment 
for  e-health  in  the  country.  This  involves  (i) developing  policies  for  effective  planning, 
implementation,  and  management  of  e-health;  (ii) advising  the  MOH  on  policies  related  to 
information  technology  security  that  will  guide  the  sharing  of  information  across  different 
institutions, health facilities, and practitioners; and (iii) providing recommendations on priorities 
and the operating framework. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
13.  The TA is estimated to cost $600,000, of which $500,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s TA Special Fund (TASF 6). The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 1. 
The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office space, 
workshop venues, and other in-kind contributions.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
14.  ADB will administer the TA. The MOH will be the executing agency, and the BHTF will 
be the implementing agency. The TA will be implemented over 2 years. Disbursements will be 
made  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Disbursement  Handbook  (2010,  as 
amended from time to time). The implementation arrangements are summarized in the table 
below.

15.  Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following its Procurement Policy 
(2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administrative instructions 
and/or staff instructions.1 The individual experts will provide specialized consulting services 
related to HIS, health financing, institutional development and capacity building, and investment 
management. Given the small contract size and the specialized nature of expertise required, the 
capacity-building agency will be selected through single-source selection.
